question: 着ける
sourceAnswer: to{} attach/join/add/append/affix/stick/glue/fasten/sew-on/apply-(ointment) | furnish-(a-house-with) | wear/put-on | keep-a-diary/make-an-entry | appraise/set-(a-price) | allot/budget/assign | bring-alongside | place-(under-guard-or-doctor) | follow/shadow | load/give-(courage-to) | keep-(an-eye-on) | establish-(relations-or-understanding) | turn-on-(light) | produce-flowers/produce-fruit

activeAnswer:
to{} <tag><ja>付ける</ja>{}attach/connect</tag> | wear/put-on | join/add | keep-a-diary/make-an-entry ...
<tag><ja>着く</ja>:<ja>える</ja>:</tag> to-be-able-to: arrive/reach/get-to
sourceMnemonic: Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: <ja>着る</ja> (to wear), <ja>着く</ja> (to arrive), and now <ja>着ける</ja> (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to <ja>着る</ja>, right? In this case, this word is like <ja>付ける</ja>, which means "to attach." It's used for things you "attach" to your body to wear, like accessories, or a face mask. That's why this is <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary>. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.
sourceReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>着く</ja>'s reading, but it might be easier to think it shares a reading with <ja>付ける</ja>, which has a similar meaning. Put on clothes, attach on clothes, etc!
